qas.question: Other than for railroads and road junction, what did Hanover have that made it a major target?
Which campaign specifically was Hanover a target for in World War II?
How many civilians were killed in the Allied bombing raids in World War II?
How many bombing raids were there during World War II?

plausible_answers.text: railroad and road junction and production center,

qas.question: What did Hanover have that made it less likely to be bombed during World War II
Which campaign specifically targeted Hanover during World War I?
How many civilians were killed during the axis bombing raids in World War II?
How many bombing raids destroyed 40% of the city?
What areas were not targeted by Allied bombers?

context: As an important <b5_0>railroad and road junction and <a0_0>production center<a0_0/>,<b5_0/> Hanover was a major target for strategic bombing during World War II, including <b6_0>the <a1_0>Oil Campaign<b6_0/><a1_0/>. Targets included the AFA (Stöcken), the Deurag-Nerag refinery (Misburg), the Continental plants (Vahrenwald and Limmer), the <a2_0>United light metal works<a2_0/> (VLW) in Ricklingen and Laatzen (today Hanover fairground), the Hanover/Limmer rubber reclamation plant, the Hanomag factory (Linden) and the tank factory M.N.H. Maschinenfabrik Niedersachsen (Badenstedt). Forced labourers were sometimes used from the Hannover-Misburg subcamp of the Neuengamme concentration camp. <b9_0>Residential areas<b9_0/> were also targeted, and <a3_0><b7_0>more than 6,000<b7_0/><a3_0/> civilians were killed by the Allied bombing raids. More than 90% of the city center was destroyed in a total of <a4_0><b8_0>88<b8_0/><a4_0/> bombing raids. After the war, the Aegidienkirche was not rebuilt and its ruins were left as a war memorial.
